  is greater than all values in a. a is assumed to be sorted.

  Examples

  julia> searchsortedfirst([1, 2, 4, 5, 5, 7], 0) # no match, insert at start
  1```

text: the definition of `xnode` is
```@inline xnode(::Type{Cell}, i, grid) = @inbounds grid.xC[i]```
<https://github.com/CliMA/Oceananigans.jl/blob/610f33576da1a3a14c6ac5fe0304478f0f2ee3f3/src/Grids/grid_utils.jl#L141>

this is a trivial use of `xnode` for sure. The main purpose of `xnode` is to make the `nodes` function easier to write. I do still think its best practice to use the function rather than manually referencing `grid.xC`, because this guards against possible future changes to the `grid` / names of `grid` properties. Also, we can ensure through dispatch that this works for other types of grids
